instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-02098: What is 820-02098? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-02020: What is 820-02020? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message:
My reference only: TT10031
Board history is unknown. Everything looks clean, no visible liquid damage.
USB-C meter is stuck at 5v. I have isolated the issue to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> by removing F5200/01.
When both fuses are removed I get 12.59v on <SIGNAL>PPVBAT_AON_CHGR_REG</SIGNAL>, but on the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> I get 1.42 which slowly drops.
When these fuses are back on, I get 6.78v something is pulling it down, .93 amps are being drawn according to the USB-C meter and <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> is getting quite hot with fuses back in place. It seems like I got a problem with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> but I cannot figure out what the problem is.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message:
Check diode mode to ground on all secondary power supplies.
Check on <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> and <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> LDOs and coils too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 103075, member: 682"]
Check diode mode to ground on all secondary power supplies.
[/QUOTE]
Could you provide me an example of a secondary power supply on this board? Keep the fuses on while checking using diode mode?
So far... Fuses still on, L8280 using diode mode shows .003v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message:
Looks like dead M1 CPU...
[URL unfurl="true"]https://openboarddata.org/?a=showboardsolutions&bpath=laptops/apple/<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>[/URL]

BTW, don't write "V" after diode mode readings; avoid any future misunderstood.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message:
Gotcha.
In the interim I did find a short coming from UR200, I have replaced it and the Diode mode reading is now .267. CPU still dead?
Looks like the link you sent me is now the correct reading. Thank you for sharing that, this is super helpful. Do you have a list of links or tools you have compiled that I could bookmark here as well?
Forgot to mention this board still stuck at the 5 volts.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message: Diode mode reading is at .066 for <SIGNAL>PP3V8AON_SW2_PH2</SIGNAL>. I did a Google search and have been looking at a prior post with you talking to another person about this same area: [URL]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-liquid-damage-short-on-<SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL>.61713/[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message:
0.066 looks to low.
Reference table specifies 0.360.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R5710</RESISTOR> is at 5.1 volts, seems a bit too high?
<RESISTOR>R5712</RESISTOR> pin 2 jumps to 1.8 when plugging in the usb-c meter but goes to 0 right away. Pin 1 is at 5 volts.
148 degrees Fahrenheit on <CHIP>U8100</CHIP>.
The row of capacitors above <CHIP>U5700</CHIP> seem to be out of character for how they are supposed to look. I will include a picture. This is also measuring in diode mode @ that .066.
Below images show <CHIP>U8100</CHIP>, and that row of capacitors above <CHIP>U5700</CHIP>. Is <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> fried? What do you think?
[ATTACH type="full"]61429[/ATTACH][ATTACH type="full"]61430[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message: You can remove the caps, one by one, and check if value jumps up from 0.066.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message:
Removed that row of caps and the diode mode reading is .062.
When I remove F5200/01, I get 12.27v on <SIGNAL>PPVBAT_AON_CHGR_REG</SIGNAL>, however when the 2 fuses are placed back on, I get 7v. Something is pulling the voltage down.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message:
What is exact resistance (ohm scale) between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL>?
Compare with good board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message:
I get 4.3m but it just keeps falling lower and lower. I had already removed <TRANSISTOR>Q5240</TRANSISTOR> when taking this measurement. Should I redo with it back on? I also do not have another board.
With <TRANSISTOR>Q5240</TRANSISTOR> still removed, pins 11 and 12 are O/L, openboarddata shows this is not correct. The other pins using diode mode seem to be close enough when measuring.
CHGR_AUX_DET_3V3 I get 0 volts. Then with diode mode I get .620. I have the two fuses off F5200/01.
When I remove the fuses, I get the 12.26volts (<SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL>), but when the fuses are on, it drops to 6volts.
I did also replace both <CHIP>U5200</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q5240</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message: If you get 12.26V at <CAPACITOR>C5250</CAPACITOR> removing F5200/1, then your problem is on the other side of the fuses (system side, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL>).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message:
Yes, I see that. I just don't know where else to go or how to track this down further. There are a bunch of resistors. <CHIP>U5700</CHIP>? 0 volts at pin 8 for <CHIP>U5700</CHIP>.
Diode mode .472 on PPVIN_P3V8AON_ISNS. Thats not too far off is it? Fuses are still off.

With fuses back on, PPVIN_P3V8AON_ISNS is 6.129volts

Diode mode: PP5V_AON_P3V8AON .511 looks good.
<SIGNAL>P3V8AON_PVCC</SIGNAL> .553 looks good.
<SIGNAL>P3V8AON_PWR_EN_R</SIGNAL> .585 looks good.
<SIGNAL>P3V8AON_LPM_R</SIGNAL> .679 spot on.
PP5V_AON_P3V8AON .518 looks good.
<SIGNAL>P3V8AON_FAULT_L</SIGNAL> .694 looks good.
<SIGNAL>P3V8AON_IMON_P3V8AON</SIGNAL> .775 looks good.
<SIGNAL>P3V8AON_GPIO</SIGNAL> .695 looks good.
<SIGNAL>P3V8AON_SS</SIGNAL> .749 looks off, supposed to be .694. I am getting .282 volts.
Am I looking in the right area?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message: With fuses in place, what is <SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL> voltage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL> voltage is: 1.48volts.
Sorry, I must have been editing my post when you wrote in. Here are my findings to your question and more I did:
With fuses back on, PPVIN_P3V8AON_ISNS is 6.129volts

Diode mode: PP5V_AON_P3V8AON .511 looks good.
<SIGNAL>P3V8AON_PVCC</SIGNAL> .553 looks good.
<SIGNAL>P3V8AON_PWR_EN_R</SIGNAL> .585 looks good.
<SIGNAL>P3V8AON_LPM_R</SIGNAL> .679 spot on.
PP5V_AON_P3V8AON .518 looks good.
<SIGNAL>P3V8AON_FAULT_L</SIGNAL> .694 looks good.
<SIGNAL>P3V8AON_IMON_P3V8AON</SIGNAL> .775 looks good.
<SIGNAL>P3V8AON_GPIO</SIGNAL> .695 looks good.
<SIGNAL>P3V8AON_SS</SIGNAL> .749 looks off, supposed to be .694. I am getting .282 volts.
Am I looking in the right area?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message:
Seems to have problems with <SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL> power supply.
Try changing <CHIP>U5700</CHIP>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message:
No dice, I had a donor board with the same chip, swapped it out, no change, the <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> chips is still heating up. I did reach back out to the customer to get further clarification on the problem and this is what he told me:
 The computer was working fine with no issues. I use it for work and it's usually on about 8 hrs a day. When I returned home I decided to update Ventura. I think it was OS 13.4, I clicked update and walked away. Upon returning the computer was dark and unresponsive.  There was nothing plugged into the computer, no peripherals, no power as the battery was fully charged.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message:
Okay, trying to isolate the problem  I have removed the following in this order: rd503, rd591, rd590. As soon as I removed I got 12.26v back on pin 2. Pin 4 and pin 3 were at first pulsing 1.4v to 1.5 but now those same pins are .500 thru .200 volts.
Yea, measuring again, it has gotta be on the PPVIN_P3V8AON_ISNS side of things. Maybe my donor board chip <CHIP>U5700</CHIP> was bad, not sure. I will try to isolate the problem further.
Another update: I removed <CHIP>U5700</CHIP> again, and I am now getting 3.8v at rd590 pin 1, so this is indeed a bad <CHIP>U5700</CHIP>?
Another update: I decided to remove <TRANSISTOR>Q5840</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q5820</TRANSISTOR>, and <TRANSISTOR>Q5800</TRANSISTOR>. When I did this, PPVIN_P3V8AON_ISNS went back to the 12.6v. <RESISTOR>R5840</RESISTOR> seems to be a connection somewhere here.
Update: <SIGNAL>P3V8AON_SW1</SIGNAL> I am getting 1.46v, and diode mode reads .025, should be .356. I have already replaced, and reflowed <CHIP>U5700</CHIP>. Bad <TRANSISTOR>Q5800</TRANSISTOR>?
Just replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q8500</TRANSISTOR> and now I have a short to ground on <SIGNAL>P3V8AON_VSW1</SIGNAL>. When I inject voltage the <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> chip gets warm just like it always has. Any other ideas? 
Hope you had a great holiday(s) by the way.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message: The above message I left edited on this past Saturday but I see responses to other peoples posts as recent as of today, could I get a response please?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message:
If machine dean on update, DFU should recover it.
But missing <SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL> doesn't allow DFU.
Not sure what could happen there...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message:
With both <TRANSISTOR>Q8500</TRANSISTOR> and L8500 removed, I do get 3.8v on <SIGNAL>P3V8AON_SW1</SIGNAL>. I also get 12.2v on PPVIN_P3V8AON_ISNS.
So I very carefully put back on <TRANSISTOR>Q8500</TRANSISTOR> and I am getting the 3.8v now on <SIGNAL>P3V8AON_VSW1</SIGNAL>, but as soon as I stick back on L5800, it brings the voltage down to 1.4v. Something on the side <SIGNAL>PP3V8AON_PH1</SIGNAL> is bring everything down.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message: Just in case, change L/<TRANSISTOR>Q5800</TRANSISTOR>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message:
I have replaced L/<TRANSISTOR>Q5800</TRANSISTOR>, <CHIP>U5700</CHIP>, <RESISTOR>R5800</RESISTOR>, and I still am getting low voltage at L5800, it is still bringing the voltage down. I got 5.04v on the amp meter and it is pulling .42 amps. 
<SIGNAL>P3V8AON_SW2</SIGNAL> diode mode reading is .03, it should be .360.
What should I try next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>P3V8AON_SW2</SIGNAL> diode mode reading is .03, it should be .360"
Did you lift L5820, to see where the low value remains?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message: Yes, 1.44v on pin 2 of L5820.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message: I was talking about 0.03 reading...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 103566, member: 682"]
"<SIGNAL>P3V8AON_SW2</SIGNAL> diode mode reading is .03, it should be .360"
Did you lift L5820, to see where the low value remains?
[/QUOTE]
Diode mode reading on pin 1 is .149
pin 2 is .030.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message:
There is common point for all 3 coils.
Why did you fix on L5820 then?

You have something pulling down <SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL> rail.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 103599, member: 682"]
Why did you fix on L5820 then?
[/QUOTE]
Sorry? I don't understand what you mean by this?
I know <SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL> is the problem but I am not sure how to narrow this down to find what exactly problem is?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message:
You've mentioned a problem with L5820.
But low diode mode reading is on its output pin; common with <SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL> power rail.
I don't know why you went for L5820.

There are many components connected, including PMICs and M1 CPU.
Is dificult to detect the culprit, once you don't have a pure short.
The problem may also be caused by some secondary power supply, derived from <SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 103620, member: 682"]
I don't know why you went for L5820.
[/QUOTE]
Oh okay, I went to that originally because when I removed all three L5820/40/00, the voltage went back up to 3.4v on pin 1 for all three. Where would you look to next then knowing this?
With L5800/20 both removed and L5840 back on, L5800 pin 1 is flucuating constantly from 4.7v to 5.7v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message:
Stop checking that point on a buck converter; there is no (pure) DC volatge!

Inject 3.5-4V into <SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL> and use thermal camera.
Give it some minutes and look for small temp diferences.
This may be waste of time...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message: Everytime I have done this, it comes back to <CHIP>U8100</CHIP>. UN400 could be an issue?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message: You can remove it and check if diode mode reading go high enough...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message: Removed <CHIP>U8100</CHIP>, <SIGNAL>PP3V8_AON</SIGNAL> is .054 diode mode. Did not go all that high.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message: The culprit is somewhere else...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message:
Okay, let me bounce this off you then if I may. Since I removed <CHIP>U8100</CHIP>, the up and down voltage on L5800 pad 1 is now for the most part stable at 3.9v. This may be because of removing <CHIP>U8100</CHIP>? However in the process, I knocked a few other components around <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> off. So I will be cleaning the area, reballing <CHIP>U8100</CHIP>, then sticking back all the components. I did however decide to take back up <TRANSISTOR>Q5800</TRANSISTOR> (after having removed <CHIP>U8100</CHIP>) cause the solder did not look so great anymore. In doing so, I did see some of the solder under <TRANSISTOR>Q5800</TRANSISTOR> looked somewhat grainy. I wonder if this may have been the issue? I keep going back to <TRANSISTOR>Q5800</TRANSISTOR> because voltage in is at 12v, but voltage going to pins 6/7/8 are off. This appears to me to be an issue?
Your thoughts/knowledge?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q5800</TRANSISTOR>'s output voltage is controlled by <CHIP>U5700</CHIP>.
Keep in mind, there is no stable DC voltage; you get that after L5800.

When replace/resolder components, always apply leaded solder on the pads first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message: Thank you. I have not put back <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> yet but poking around <SIGNAL>P3V8AON_VSENSE</SIGNAL> diode mode reading is .05, should be .356. What is this sensing? I keep coming back to this area too but NOSTUFF is in this area.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message: Remove <RESISTOR>R5870</RESISTOR> and see where the low reading remains.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message:
Diode mode shows pin 1 @ .053
pin 2 shows @ .770.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5v
threads.message: So your problem is still on pin 1 (<SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL>).
